title: 6Â  Additional space
text:
6.3. Recursion
In the last two sections, we saw that we can prove that all natural numbers have some property by proving that 0 has the property, and also that for every natural number \(n\), if \(n\) has the property then so does \(n + 1\). In this section we will see that a similar idea can be used to define a function whose domain is the natural numbers. We can define a function \(f\) with domain \(\mathbb{N}\) by specifying the value of \(f(0)\), and also saying how to compute \(f(n+1)\) if you already know the value of \(f(n)\).
For example, we can define a function \(f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}\) as follows:

\(f(0) = 1\); for every \(n \in \mathbb{N}\), \(f(n+1) = (n+1) \cdot f(n)\).

Here is the same definition written in Lean. (For reasons that will become clear shortly, we have given the function the name fact.)
def fact (k : Nat) : Nat :=
  match k with
    | 0 => 1
    | n + 1 => (n + 1) * fact n
Lean can use this definition to compute fact k for any natural number k. The match statement tells Lean to try to match the input k with one of the two patterns 0 and n + 1, and then to use the corresponding formula after => to compute fact k. For example, if we ask Lean for fact 4, it first checks if 4 matches 0. Since it doesnâ€™t, it goes on to the next line and determines that 4 matches the pattern n + 1, with n = 3, so it uses the formula fact 4 = 4 * fact 3. Of course, now it must compute fact 3, which it does in the same way: 3 matches n + 1 with n = 2, so fact 3 = 3 * fact 2. Continuing in this way, Lean determines that

fact 4 = 4 * fact 3 = 4 * (3 * fact 2) = 4 * (3 * (2 * fact 1))
       = 4 * (3 * (2 * (1 * fact 0))) = 4 * (3 * (2 * (1 * 1))) = 24.

You can confirm this with the #eval command:
#eval fact 4   --Answer: 24
Of course, by now you have probably guessed why we used the name fact for his function: fact k is k factorialâ€”the product of all the numbers from 1 to k.
This style of definition is called a recursive definition. If a function is defined by a recursive definition, then theorems about that function are often most easily proven by induction. For example, here is a theorem about the factorial function. It is Example 6.3.1 in HTPI, and we begin the Lean proof by imitating the proof in HTPI.
theorem ??Example_6_3_1:: : âˆ€ n â‰¥ 4, fact n > 2 ^ n := by
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    norm_num
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume h1 : n â‰¥ 4
    assume ih : fact n > 2 ^ n
    show fact (n + 1) > 2 ^ (n + 1) from
      calc fact (n + 1)
        _ = (n + 1) * fact n := by rfl
        _ > (n + 1) * 2 ^ n := sorry
        _ > 2 * 2 ^ n := sorry
        _ = 2 ^ (n + 1) := by ring
    done
  done
There are two steps in the calculational proof at the end that require justification. The first says that (n + 1) * fact n > (n + 1) * 2 ^ n, which should follow from the inductive hypothesis ih : fact n > 2 ^ n by multiplying both sides by n + 1. Is there a theorem that would justify this inference?
This may remind you of a step in Example_6_1_3 where we used the theorem Nat.mul_le_mul_right, which says âˆ€ {n m : â„•} (k : â„•), n â‰¤ m â†’ n * k â‰¤ m * k. Our situation in this example is similar, but it involves a strict inequality (> rather than â‰¥) and it involves multiplying on the left rather than the right. Many theorems about inequalities in Leanâ€™s library contain either le (for â€œless than or equal toâ€) or lt (for â€œless thanâ€) in their names, but they can also be used to prove statements involving â‰¥ or >. Perhaps the theorem we need is named something like Nat.mul_lt_mul_left. If you type #check @Nat.mul_lt_mul into VS Code, a pop-up window will appear listing several theorems that begin with Nat.mul_lt_mul. There is no Nat.mul_lt_mul_left, but there is a theorem called Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_left, and its meaning is

@Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_left : âˆ€ {n m k : â„•},
                                n < m â†’ k > 0 â†’ k * n < k * m

Lean has correctly reminded us that, to multiply both sides of a strict inequality by a number k, we need to know that k > 0. So in our case, weâ€™ll need to prove that n + 1 > 0. Once we have that, we can use the theorem Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_left to eliminate the first sorry.
The second sorry is similar: (n + 1) * 2 ^ n > 2 * 2 ^ n should follow from n + 1 > 2 and 2 ^ n > 0, and you can verify that the theorem that will justify this inference is Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_right.
So we have three inequalities that we need to prove before we can justify the steps of the calculational proof: n + 1 > 0, n + 1 > 2, and 2 ^ n > 0. Weâ€™ll insert have steps before the calculational proof to assert these three inequalities. If you try it, youâ€™ll find that linarith can prove the first two, but not the third.
How can we prove 2 ^ n > 0? It is often helpful to think about whether there is a general principle that is behind a statement we are trying to prove. In our case, the inequality 2 ^ n > 0 is an instance of the general fact that if m and n are any natural numbers with m > 0, then m ^ n > 0. Maybe that fact is in Leanâ€™s library:
example (m n : Nat) (h : m > 0) : m ^ n > 0 := by ++apply?::
The apply? tactic comes up with exact Nat.pos_pow_of_pos n h, and #check @pos_pow_of_pos gives the result

@Nat.pos_pow_of_pos : âˆ€ {n : â„•} (m : â„•), 0 < n â†’ 0 < n ^ m

That means that we can use Nat.pos_pow_of_pos to prove 2 ^ n > 0, but first weâ€™ll need to prove that 2 > 0. We now have all the pieces we need; putting them together leads to this proof:
theorem Example_6_3_1 : âˆ€ n â‰¥ 4, fact n > 2 ^ n := by
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    norm_num
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume h1 : n â‰¥ 4
    assume ih : fact n > 2 ^ n
    have h2 : n + 1 > 0 := by linarith
    have h3 : n + 1 > 2 := by linarith
    have h4 : 2 > 0 := by linarith
    have h5 : 2 ^ n > 0 := Nat.pos_pow_of_pos n h4
    show fact (n + 1) > 2 ^ (n + 1) from
      calc fact (n + 1)
        _ = (n + 1) * fact n := by rfl
        _ > (n + 1) * 2 ^ n := Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_left ih h2
        _ > 2 * 2 ^ n := Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_right h3 h5
        _ = 2 ^ (n + 1) := by ring
    done
  done
But there is an easier way. Look at the two â€œ>â€ steps in the calculational proof at the end of Example_6_3_1. In both cases, we took a known relationship between two quantities and did something to both sides that preserved the relationship. In the first case, the known relationship was ih : fact n > 2 ^ n, and we multiplied both sides by n + 1 on the left; in the second, the known relationship was h3 : n + 1 > 2, and we multiplied both sides by 2 ^ n on the right. To justify these steps, we had to find the right theorems in Leanâ€™s library, and we ended up needing auxiliary positivity facts: h2 : n + 1 > 0 in the first case and h5 : 2 ^ n > 0 in the second. There is a tactic that can simplify these steps: if h is a proof of a statement asserting a relationship between two quantities, then the tactic rel [h] will attempt to prove any statement obtained from that relationship by applying the same operation to both sides. The tactic will try to find a theorem in Leanâ€™s library that says that the operation preserves the relationship, and if the theorem requires auxiliary positivity facts, it will try to prove those facts as well. The rel tactic doesnâ€™t always succeed, but when it does, it saves you the trouble of searching through the library for the necessary theorems. In this case, the tactic allows us to give a much simpler proof of Example_6_3_1:
theorem Example_6_3_1 : âˆ€ n â‰¥ 4, fact n > 2 ^ n := by
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    norm_num
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume h1 : n â‰¥ 4
    assume ih : fact n > 2 ^ n
    have h2 : n + 1 > 2 := by linarith
    show fact (n + 1) > 2 ^ (n + 1) from
      calc fact (n + 1)
        _ = (n + 1) * fact n := by rfl
        _ > (n + 1) * 2 ^ n := by rel [ih]
        _ > 2 * 2 ^ n := by rel [h2]
        _ = 2 ^ (n + 1) := by ring
    done
  done
The next example in HTPI is a proof of one of the laws of exponents: a ^ (m + n) = a ^ m * a ^ n. Leanâ€™s definition of exponentiation with natural number exponents is recursive. For some reason, the definitions are slightly different for different kinds of bases. The definitions Lean uses are essentially as follows:
--For natural numbers b and k, b ^ k = nat_pow b k:
def nat_pow (b k : Nat) : Nat :=
  match k with
    | 0 => 1
    | n + 1 => (nat_pow b n) * b

--For a real number b and a natural number k, b ^ k = real_pow b k:
def real_pow (b : Real) (k : Nat) : Real :=
  match k with
    | 0 => 1
    | n + 1 => b * (real_pow b n)
Letâ€™s prove the addition law for exponents:
theorem Example_6_3_2_cheating : âˆ€ (a : Real) (m n : Nat),
    a ^ (m + n) = a ^ m * a ^ n := by
  fix a : Real; fix m : Nat; fix n : Nat
  ring
  done
Well, that wasnâ€™t really fair. The ring tactic knows the laws of exponents, so it has no trouble proving this theorem. But we want to know why the law holds, so letâ€™s see if we can prove it without using ring. The following proof is essentially the same as the proof in HTPI:
theorem Example_6_3_2 : âˆ€ (a : Real) (m n : Nat),
    a ^ (m + n) = a ^ m * a ^ n := by
  fix a : Real; fix m : Nat
    --Goal : âˆ€ (n : Nat), a ^ (m + n) = a ^ m * a ^ n
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    show a ^ (m + 0) = a ^ m * a ^ 0 from
      calc a ^ (m + 0)
        _ = a ^ m := by rfl
        _ = a ^ m * 1 := (mul_one (a ^ m)).symm
        _ = a ^ m * a ^ 0 := by rfl
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : a ^ (m + n) = a ^ m * a ^ n
    show a ^ (m + (n + 1)) = a ^ m * a ^ (n + 1) from
      calc a ^ (m + (n + 1))
        _ = a ^ ((m + n) + 1) := by rw [add_assoc]
        _ = a * a ^ (m + n) := by rfl
        _ = a * (a ^ m * a ^ n) := by rw [ih]
        _ = a ^ m * (a * a ^ n) := by
              rw [â†mul_assoc, mul_comm a, mul_assoc]
        _ = a ^ m * (a ^ (n + 1)) := by rfl
    done
  done
Finally, weâ€™ll prove the theorem in Example 6.3.4 of HTPI, which again involves exponentiation with natural number exponents. Hereâ€™s the beginning of the proof:


theorem Example_6_3_4 : âˆ€ (x : Real), x > -1 â†’
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x := by
  fix x : Real
  assume h1 : x > -1
  **done::


x : â„
h1 : x > -1
âŠ¢ âˆ€ (n : â„•),
>>  (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥
>>    1 + â†‘n * x


Look carefully at the goal in the tactic state. Why is there a â†‘ before the last n? The reason has to do with types. The variable x has type Real and n has type Nat, so how can Lean multiply n by x? Remember, in Lean, the natural numbers are not a subset of the real numbers. The two types are completely separate, but for each natural number, there is a corresponding real number. To multiply n by x, Lean had to convert n to the corresponding real number, through a process called coercion. The notation â†‘n denotes the result of coercing (or casting) n to another typeâ€”in this case, Real. Since â†‘n and x are both real numbers, Lean can use the multiplication operation on the real numbers to multiply them. (To type â†‘ in VSCode, type \uparrow, or just \u.)
As we will see, the need for coercion in this example will make the proof a bit more complicated, because weâ€™ll need to use some theorems about coercions. Theorems about coercion of natural numbers to some other type often have names that start Nat.cast.
Continuing with the proof, since exponentiation is defined recursively, letâ€™s try mathematical induction:


theorem Example_6_3_4 : âˆ€ (x : Real), x > -1 â†’
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x := by
  fix x : Real
  assume h1 : x > -1
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case

    **done::
  Â· -- Induction Step

    **done::  
  done


case Base_Case
x : â„
h1 : x > -1
âŠ¢ (1 + x) ^ 0 â‰¥
>>  1 + â†‘0 * x


You might think that linarith could prove the goal for the base case, but it canâ€™t. The problem is the â†‘0, which denotes the result of coercing the natural number 0 to a real number. Of course, that should be the real number 0, but is it? Yes, but the linarith tactic doesnâ€™t know that. The theorem Nat.cast_zero says that â†‘0 = 0 (where the 0 on the right side of the equation is the real number 0), so the tactic rewrite [Nat.cast_zero] will convert â†‘0 to 0. After that step, linarith can complete the proof of the base case, and we can start on the induction step.


theorem Example_6_3_4 : âˆ€ (x : Real), x > -1 â†’
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x := by
  fix x : Real
  assume h1 : x > -1
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    rewrite [Nat.cast_zero]
    linarith
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x
    **done::
  done


case Induction_Step
x : â„
h1 : x > -1
n : â„•
ih : (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥
>>    1 + â†‘n * x
âŠ¢ (1 + x) ^ (n + 1) â‰¥
>>  1 + â†‘(n + 1) * x


Once again, thereâ€™s a complication caused by coercion. The inductive hypothesis talks about â†‘n, but the goal involves â†‘(n + 1). What is the relationship between these? Surely it should be the case that â†‘(n + 1) = â†‘n + 1; that is, the result of coercing the natural number n + 1 to a real number should be one larger than the result of coercing n to a real number. The theorem Nat.cast_succ says exactly that, so rewrite [Nat.cast_succ] will change the â†‘(n + 1) in the goal to â†‘n + 1. (The number n + 1 is sometimes called the successor of n, and succ is short for â€œsuccessor.â€) With that change, we can continue with the proof. The following proof is modeled on the proof in HTPI.
theorem ??Example_6_3_4:: : âˆ€ (x : Real), x > -1 â†’
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x := by
  fix x : Real
  assume h1 : x > -1
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    rewrite [Nat.cast_zero]
    linarith
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x
    rewrite [Nat.cast_succ]
    show (1 + x) ^ (n + 1) â‰¥ 1 + (n + 1) * x from
      calc (1 + x) ^ (n + 1)
        _ = (1 + x) * (1 + x) ^ n := by rfl
        _ â‰¥ (1 + x) * (1 + n * x) := sorry
        _ = 1 + x + n * x + n * x ^ 2 := by ring
        _ â‰¥ 1 + x + n * x + 0 := sorry
        _ = 1 + (n + 1) * x := by ring
    done
  done
Note that in the calculational proof, each n or n + 1 that is multiplied by x is really â†‘n or â†‘n + 1, but we donâ€™t need to say so explicitly; Lean fills in coercions automatically when they are required.
All thatâ€™s left is to replace the two occurrences of sorry with justifications. The first sorry step should follow from the inductive hypothesis by multiplying both sides by 1 + x, so a natural attempt to justify it would be by rel [ih]. Unfortunately, we get an error message saying that rel failed. The error message tells us that rel needed to know that 0 â‰¤ 1 + x, and it was unable to prove it, so weâ€™ll have to provide a proof of that statement ourselves. Fortunately, linarith can handle it (deducing it from h1 : x > -1), and once we fill in that additional step, the rel tactic succeeds.
theorem ??Example_6_3_4:: : âˆ€ (x : Real), x > -1 â†’
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x := by
  fix x : Real
  assume h1 : x > -1
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    rewrite [Nat.cast_zero]
    linarith
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x
    rewrite [Nat.cast_succ]
    have h2 : 0 â‰¤ 1 + x := by linarith
    show (1 + x) ^ (n + 1) â‰¥ 1 + (n + 1) * x from
      calc (1 + x) ^ (n + 1)
        _ = (1 + x) * (1 + x) ^ n := by rfl
        _ â‰¥ (1 + x) * (1 + n * x) := by rel [ih]
        _ = 1 + x + n * x + n * x ^ 2 := by ring
        _ â‰¥ 1 + x + n * x + 0 := sorry
        _ = 1 + (n + 1) * x := by ring
    done
  done
For the second sorry step, weâ€™ll need to know that n * x ^ 2 â‰¥ 0. To prove it, we start with the fact that the square of any real number is nonnegative:

@sq_nonneg : âˆ€ {R : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedRing R]
              (a : R), 0 â‰¤ a ^ 2

As usual, we donâ€™t need to pay much attention to the implicit arguments; what is important is the last line, which tells us that sq_nonneg x is a proof of x ^ 2 â‰¥ 0. To get n * x ^ 2 â‰¥ 0 we just have to multiply both sides by n, which we can justify with the rel tactic, and then one more application of rel will handle the remaining sorry. Here is the complete proof:
theorem Example_6_3_4 : âˆ€ (x : Real), x > -1 â†’
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x := by
  fix x : Real
  assume h1 : x > -1
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    rewrite [Nat.cast_zero]
    linarith
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : (1 + x) ^ n â‰¥ 1 + n * x
    rewrite [Nat.cast_succ]
    have h2 : 0 â‰¤ 1 + x := by linarith
    have h3 : x ^ 2 â‰¥ 0 := sq_nonneg x
    have h4 : n * x ^ 2 â‰¥ 0 :=
      calc n * x ^ 2
        _ â‰¥ n * 0 := by rel [h3]
        _ = 0 := by ring
    show (1 + x) ^ (n + 1) â‰¥ 1 + (n + 1) * x from
      calc (1 + x) ^ (n + 1)
        _ = (1 + x) * (1 + x) ^ n := by rfl
        _ â‰¥ (1 + x) * (1 + n * x) := by rel [ih]
        _ = 1 + x + n * x + n * x ^ 2 := by ring
        _ â‰¥ 1 + x + n * x + 0 := by rel [h4]
        _ = 1 + (n + 1) * x := by ring
    done
  done
Before ending this section, weâ€™ll return to a topic left unexplained before. We can now describe how Sum i from k to n, f i is defined. The key is a function sum_seq, which is defined by recursion:
def sum_seq {A : Type} [AddZeroClass A]
    (m k : Nat) (f : Nat â†’ A) : A :=
  match m with
    | 0 => 0
    | n + 1 => sum_seq n k f + f (k + n)
To get an idea of what this definition means, letâ€™s try evaluating sum_seq 3 k f:

sum_seq 3 k f = sum_seq 2 k f + f (k + 2)
              = sum_seq 1 k f + f (k + 1) + f (k + 2)
              = sum_seq 0 k f + f (k + 0) + f (k + 1) + f (k + 2)
              = 0 + f (k + 0) + f (k + 1) + f (k + 2)
              = f k + f (k + 1) + f (k + 2).

So sum_seq 3 k f adds up three consecutive values of f, starting with f k. More generally, sum_seq n k f adds up a sequence of n consecutive values of f, starting with f k. (The implicit arguments say that the type of the values of f can be any type for which + and 0 make sense.) The notation Sum i from k to n, f i is now defined to be a shorthand for sum_seq (n + 1 - k) k f. Weâ€™ll leave it to you to puzzle out why that gives the desired result.

Exercises

theorem Exercise_6_3_4 : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    3 * (Sum i from 0 to n, (2 * i + 1) ^ 2) =
    (n + 1) * (2 * n + 1) * (2 * n + 3) := sorry


theorem Exercise_6_3_7b (f : Nat â†’ Real) (c : Real) : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    Sum i from 0 to n, c * f i = c * Sum i from 0 to n, f i := sorry


theorem fact_pos : âˆ€ (n : Nat), fact n â‰¥ 1 := sorry


--Hint:  Use the theorem fact_pos from the previous exercise.
theorem Exercise_6_3_13a (k : Nat) : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    fact (k ^ 2 + n) â‰¥ k ^ (2 * n) := sorry


--Hint:  Use the theorem in the previous exercise.
--You may find it useful to first prove a lemma:
--âˆ€ (k : Nat), 2 * k ^ 2 + 1 â‰¥ k
theorem Exercise_6_3_13b (k : Nat) : âˆ€ n â‰¥ 2 * k ^ 2,
    fact n â‰¥ k ^ n := sorry

6. A sequence is defined recursively as follows:
def seq_6_3_15 (k : Nat) : Int :=
  match k with
    | 0 => 0
    | n + 1 => 2 * seq_6_3_15 n + n
Prove the following theorem about this sequence:
theorem Exercise_6_3_15 : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    seq_6_3_15 n = 2 ^ n - n - 1 := sorry
7. A sequence is defined recursively as follows:
def seq_6_3_16 (k : Nat) : Nat :=
  match k with
    | 0 => 2
    | n + 1 => (seq_6_3_16 n) ^ 2
Find a formula for seq_6_3_16 n. Fill in the blank in the theorem below with your formula and then prove the theorem.
theorem Exercise_6_3_16 : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    seq_6_3_16 n = ___ := sorry

title: 6Â  Additional space
text:
6.4. Strong Induction
In the induction step of a proof by mathematical induction, we prove that a natural number has some property from the assumption that the previous number has the property. Section 6.4 of HTPI introduces a version of mathematical induction in which we get to assume that all smaller numbers have the property. Since this is a stronger assumption, this version of induction is called strong induction. Here is how strong induction works (HTPI p.Â 304):

To prove a goal of the form âˆ€ (n : Nat), P n:

Prove that âˆ€ (n : Nat), (âˆ€ n_1 < n, P n_1) â†’ P n.

To write a proof by strong induction in Lean, we use the tactic by_strong_induc, whose effect on the tactic state can be illustrated as follows.


>> â‹®
âŠ¢ âˆ€ (n : Nat), P n


>> â‹®
âŠ¢  âˆ€ (n : Nat),
>>  (âˆ€ n_1 < n, P n_1) â†’ P n


To illustrate this, we begin with Example 6.4.1 of HTPI.
theorem Example_6_4_1 : âˆ€ m > 0, âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m
Imitating the strategy of the proof in HTPI, we let m be an arbitrary natural number, assume m > 0, and then prove the statement âˆ€ (n : Nat), âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m by strong induction. That means that after introducing an arbitrary natural number n, we assume the inductive hypothesis, which says âˆ€ n_1 < n, âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n_1 = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m.
theorem Example_6_4_1 : âˆ€ m > 0, âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m := by
  fix m : Nat
  assume h1 : m > 0
  by_strong_induc
  fix n : Nat
  assume ih : âˆ€ n_1 < n, âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n_1 = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m
  **done::
Our goal now is to prove that âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m. Although strong induction does not require a base case, it is not uncommon for proofs by strong induction to involve reasoning by cases. The proof in HTPI uses cases based on whether or not n < m. If n < m, then the proof is easy: the numbers q = 0 and râ€‹ = n clearly have the required properties. If Â¬n < m, then we can write n as n = k + m, for some natural number k. Since m > 0, we have k < n, so we can apply the inductive hypothesis to k. Notice that if m > 1, then k is not the number immediately preceding n; thatâ€™s why this proof uses strong induction rather than ordinary induction.
How do we come up with the number k in the previous paragraph? Weâ€™ll use a theorem from Leanâ€™s library. There are two slightly different versions of the theoremâ€”notice that the first ends with m + k and the second ends with k + m:

@Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le : âˆ€ {m n : â„•}, m â‰¤ n â†’ âˆƒ (k : â„•), n = m + k

@Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le' : âˆ€ {m n : â„•}, m â‰¤ n â†’ âˆƒ (k : â„•), n = k + m

Weâ€™ll use the second version in our proof.
theorem Example_6_4_1 : âˆ€ m > 0, âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m := by
  fix m : Nat
  assume h1 : m > 0
  by_strong_induc
  fix n : Nat
  assume ih : âˆ€ n_1 < n, âˆƒ (q r : Nat), n_1 = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m
  by_cases h2 : n < m
  Â· -- Case 1. h2 : n < m
    apply Exists.intro 0
    apply Exists.intro n     --Goal : n = m * 0 + n âˆ§ n < m
    apply And.intro _ h2
    ring
    done
  Â· -- Case 2. h2 : Â¬n < m
    have h3 : m â‰¤ n := by linarith
    obtain (k : Nat) (h4 : n = k + m) from Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le' h3
    have h5 : k < n := by linarith
    have h6 : âˆƒ (q r : Nat), k = m * q + r âˆ§ r < m := ih k h5
    obtain (q' : Nat)
      (h7 : âˆƒ (r : Nat), k = m * q' + r âˆ§ r < m) from h6
    obtain (r' : Nat) (h8 : k = m * q' + r' âˆ§ r' < m) from h7
    apply Exists.intro (q' + 1)
    apply Exists.intro r'     --Goal : n = m * (q' + 1) + r' âˆ§ r' < m
    apply And.intro _ h8.right
    show n = m * (q' + 1) + r' from
      calc n
        _ = k + m := h4
        _ = m * q' + r' + m := by rw [h8.left]
        _ = m * (q' + 1) + r' := by ring
    done
  done
The numbers q and r in Example_6_4_1 are called the quotient and remainder when n is divided by m. Lean knows how to compute these numbers: if n and m are natural numbers, then in Lean, n / m denotes the quotient when n is divided by m, and n % m denotes the remainder. (The number n % m is also sometimes called n modulo m, or n mod m.) And Lean knows theorems stating that these numbers have the properties specified in Example_6_4_1:

@Nat.div_add_mod : âˆ€ (m n : â„•), n * (m / n) + m % n = m

@Nat.mod_lt : âˆ€ (x : â„•) {y : â„•}, y > 0 â†’ x % y < y

By the way, although we are unlikely to want to use the notation n / 0 or n % 0, Lean uses the definitions n / 0 = 0 and n % 0 = n. As a result, the equation n * (m / n) + m % n = m is true even if n = 0. Thatâ€™s why the theorem Nat.div_add_mod doesnâ€™t include a requirement that n > 0. It is important to keep in mind that division of natural numbers is not the same as division of real numbers. For example, dividing the natural number 5 by the natural number 2 gives a quotient of 2 (with a remainder of 1), so (5 : Nat) / (2 : Nat) is 2, but (5 : Real) / (2 : Real) is 2.5.
There is also a strong form of recursion. As an example of this, here is a recursive definition of a sequence of numbers called the Fibonacci numbers:
def Fib (n : Nat) : Nat :=
  match n with
    | 0 => 0
    | 1 => 1
    | k + 2 => Fib k + Fib (k + 1)
Notice that the formula for Fib (k + 2) involves the two previous values of Fib, not just the immediately preceding value. That is the sense in which the recursion is strong. Not surprisingly, theorems about the Fibonacci numbers are often proven by inductionâ€”either ordinary or strong. Weâ€™ll illustrate this with a proof by strong induction that âˆ€ (n : Nat), Fib n < 2 ^ n. This time weâ€™ll need to treat the cases n = 0 and n = 1 separately, since these values are treated separately in the definition of Fib n. And weâ€™ll need to know that if n doesnâ€™t fall into either of those cases, then it falls into the third case: n = k + 2 for some natural number k. Since similar ideas will come up several times in the rest of this book, it will be useful to begin by proving lemmas that will help with this kind of reasoning.
Weâ€™ll need two theorems from Leanâ€™s library, the second of which has two slightly different versions:

@Nat.pos_of_ne_zero : âˆ€ {n : â„•}, n â‰  0 â†’ 0 < n

@lt_of_le_of_ne : âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : PartialOrder Î±] {a b : Î±},
                    a â‰¤ b â†’ a â‰  b â†’ a < b

@lt_of_le_of_ne' : âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} [inst : PartialOrder Î±] {a b : Î±},
                    a â‰¤ b â†’ b â‰  a â†’ a < b

If we have h1 : n â‰  0, then Nat.pos_of_ne_zero h1 is a proof of 0 < n. But for natural numbers a and b, Lean treats a < b as meaning the same thing as a + 1 â‰¤ b, so this is also a proof of 1 â‰¤ n. If we also have h2 : n â‰  1, then we can use lt_of_le_of_ne' to conclude 1 < n, which is definitionally equal to 2 â‰¤ n. Combining this reasoning with the theorem Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le', which we used in the last example, we can prove two lemmas that will be helpful for reasoning in which the first one or two natural numbers have to be treated separately.
lemma exists_eq_add_one_of_ne_zero {n : Nat}
    (h1 : n â‰  0) : âˆƒ (k : Nat), n = k + 1 := by
  have h2 : 1 â‰¤ n := Nat.pos_of_ne_zero h1
  show âˆƒ (k : Nat), n = k + 1 from Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le' h2
  done

theorem exists_eq_add_two_of_ne_zero_one {n : Nat}
    (h1 : n â‰  0) (h2 : n â‰  1) : âˆƒ (k : Nat), n = k + 2 := by
  have h3 : 1 â‰¤ n := Nat.pos_of_ne_zero h1
  have h4 : 2 â‰¤ n := lt_of_le_of_ne' h3 h2
  show âˆƒ (k : Nat), n = k + 2 from Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le' h4
  done
With this preparation, we can present the proof:
example : âˆ€ (n : Nat), Fib n < 2 ^ n := by
  by_strong_induc
  fix n : Nat
  assume ih : âˆ€ (n_1 : Nat), n_1 < n â†’ Fib n_1 < 2 ^ n_1
  by_cases h1 : n = 0
  Â· -- Case 1. h1 : n = 0
    rewrite [h1]   --Goal : Fib 0 < 2 ^ 0
    norm_num
    done
  Â· -- Case 2. h1 : Â¬n = 0
    by_cases h2 : n = 1
    Â· -- Case 2.1. h2 : n = 1
      rewrite [h2]
      norm_num
      done
    Â· -- Case 2.2. h2 : Â¬n = 1
      obtain (k : Nat) (h3 : n = k + 2) from
        exists_eq_add_two_of_ne_zero_one h1 h2
      have h4 : k < n := by linarith
      have h5 : Fib k < 2 ^ k := ih k h4
      have h6 : k + 1 < n := by linarith
      have h7 : Fib (k + 1) < 2 ^ (k + 1) := ih (k + 1) h6
      rewrite [h3]            --Goal : Fib (k + 2) < 2 ^ (k + 2)
      show Fib (k + 2) < 2 ^ (k + 2) from
        calc Fib (k + 2)
          _ = Fib k + Fib (k + 1) := by rfl
          _ < 2 ^ k + Fib (k + 1) := by rel [h5]
          _ < 2 ^ k + 2 ^ (k + 1) := by rel [h7]
          _ â‰¤ 2 ^ k + 2 ^ (k + 1) + 2 ^ k := by linarith
          _ = 2 ^ (k + 2) := by ring
      done
    done
  done
As with ordinary induction, strong induction can be useful for proving statements that do not at first seem to have the form âˆ€ (n : Nat), .... To illustrate this, weâ€™ll prove the well-ordering principle, which says that if a set S : Set Nat is nonempty, then it has a smallest element. Weâ€™ll prove the contrapositive: if S has no smallest element, then it is empty. To say that S is empty means âˆ€ (n : Nat), n âˆ‰ S, and thatâ€™s the statement to which we will apply strong induction.
theorem well_ord_princ (S : Set Nat) : (âˆƒ (n : Nat), n âˆˆ S) â†’
    âˆƒ (n : Nat), n âˆˆ S âˆ§ âˆ€ (m : Nat), m âˆˆ S â†’ n â‰¤ m := by
  contrapos
  assume h1 : Â¬âˆƒ (n : Nat), n âˆˆ S âˆ§ âˆ€ (m : Nat), m âˆˆ S â†’ n â‰¤ m
  quant_neg                   --Goal : âˆ€ (n : Nat), Â¬n âˆˆ S
  by_strong_induc
  fix n : Nat
  assume ih : âˆ€ (n_1 : Nat), n_1 < n â†’ Â¬n_1 âˆˆ S  --Goal : Â¬n âˆˆ S
  contradict h1 with h2       --h2 : n âˆˆ S
    --Goal : âˆƒ (n : Nat), n âˆˆ S âˆ§ âˆ€ (m : Nat), m âˆˆ S â†’ n â‰¤ m
  apply Exists.intro n
  apply And.intro h2          --Goal : âˆ€ (m : Nat), m âˆˆ S â†’ n â‰¤ m
  fix m : Nat
  assume h3 : m âˆˆ S
  have h4 : m < n â†’ Â¬m âˆˆ S := ih m
  contrapos at h4             --h4 : m âˆˆ S â†’ Â¬m < n
  have h5 : Â¬m < n := h4 h3
  linarith
  done
Section 6.4 of HTPI ends with an example of an application of the well ordering principle. The example gives a proof that \(\sqrt{2}\) is irrational. If \(\sqrt{2}\) were rational, then there would be natural numbers \(p\) and \(q\) such that \(q \ne 0\) and \(p/q = \sqrt{2}\), and therefore \(p^2 = 2q^2\). So we can prove that \(\sqrt{2}\) is irrational by showing that there do not exist natural numbers \(p\) and \(q\) such that \(q \ne 0\) and \(p^2 = 2q^2\).
The proof uses a definition from the exercises of Section 6.1:
def nat_even (n : Nat) : Prop := âˆƒ (k : Nat), n = 2 * k
We will also use the following lemma, whose proof we leave as an exercise for you:
lemma sq_even_iff_even (n : Nat) : nat_even (n * n) â†” nat_even n := sorry
And weâ€™ll need another theorem that we havenâ€™t seen before:

@mul_left_cancel_iff_of_pos : âˆ€ {Î± : Type u_1} {a b c : Î±}
                    [inst : MulZeroClass Î±] [inst_1 : PartialOrder Î±]
                    [inst_2 : PosMulMonoRev Î±],
                    0 < a â†’ (a * b = a * c â†” b = c)

To show that \(\sqrt{2}\) is irrational, we will prove the statement

Â¬âˆƒ (q p : Nat), p * p = 2 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0

We proceed by contradiction. If this statement were false, then the set

S = { q : Nat | âˆƒ (p : Nat), p * p = 2 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0 }

would be nonempty, and therefore, by the well ordering principle, it would have a smallest element. We then show that this leads to a contradiction. Here is the proof.
theorem Theorem_6_4_5 :
    Â¬âˆƒ (q p : Nat), p * p = 2 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0 := by
  set S : Set Nat :=
    { q : Nat | âˆƒ (p : Nat), p * p = 2 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0 }
  by_contra h1
  have h2 : âˆƒ (q : Nat), q âˆˆ S := h1
  have h3 : âˆƒ (q : Nat), q âˆˆ S âˆ§ âˆ€ (r : Nat), r âˆˆ S â†’ q â‰¤ r :=
    well_ord_princ S h2
  obtain (q : Nat) (h4 : q âˆˆ S âˆ§ âˆ€ (r : Nat), r âˆˆ S â†’ q â‰¤ r) from h3
  have qinS : q âˆˆ S := h4.left
  have qleast : âˆ€ (r : â„•), r âˆˆ S â†’ q â‰¤ r := h4.right
  define at qinS     --qinS : âˆƒ (p : Nat), p * p = 2 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0
  obtain (p : Nat) (h5 : p * p = 2 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0) from qinS
  have pqsqrt2 : p * p = 2 * (q * q) := h5.left
  have qne0 : q â‰  0 := h5.right
  have h6 : nat_even (p * p) := Exists.intro (q * q) pqsqrt2
  rewrite [sq_even_iff_even p] at h6    --h6 : nat_even p
  obtain (p' : Nat) (p'halfp : p = 2 * p') from h6
  have h7 : 2 * (2 * (p' * p')) = 2 * (q * q) := by
    rewrite [â†pqsqrt2, p'halfp]
    ring
    done
  have h8 : 2 > 0 := by norm_num
  rewrite [mul_left_cancel_iff_of_pos h8] at h7
    --h7 : 2 * (p' * p') = q * q
  have h9 : nat_even (q * q) := Exists.intro (p' * p') h7.symm
  rewrite [sq_even_iff_even q] at h9   --h9 : nat_even q
  obtain (q' : Nat) (q'halfq : q = 2 * q') from h9
  have h10 : 2 * (p' * p') = 2 * (2 * (q' * q')) := by
    rewrite [h7, q'halfq]
    ring
    done
  rewrite [mul_left_cancel_iff_of_pos h8] at h10
    --h10 : p' * p' = 2 * (q' * q')
  have q'ne0 : q' â‰  0 := by
    contradict qne0 with h11
    rewrite [q'halfq, h11]
    rfl
    done
  have q'inS : q' âˆˆ S := Exists.intro p' (And.intro h10 q'ne0)
  have qleq' : q â‰¤ q' := qleast q' q'inS
  rewrite [q'halfq] at qleq'        --qleq' : 2 * q' â‰¤ q'
  contradict q'ne0
  linarith
  done


Exercises

--Hint: Use Exercise_6_1_16a1 and Exercise_6_1_16a2
--from the exercises of Section 6.1.
lemma sq_even_iff_even (n : Nat) :
    nat_even (n * n) â†” nat_even n := sorry


--This theorem proves that the square root of 6 is irrational
theorem Exercise_6_4_4a :
    Â¬âˆƒ (q p : Nat), p * p = 6 * (q * q) âˆ§ q â‰  0 := sorry


theorem Exercise_6_4_5 :
    âˆ€ n â‰¥ 12, âˆƒ (a b : Nat), 3 * a + 7 * b = n := sorry


theorem Exercise_6_4_7a : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    (Sum i from 0 to n, Fib i) + 1 = Fib (n + 2) := sorry


theorem Exercise_6_4_7c : âˆ€ (n : Nat),
    Sum i from 0 to n, Fib (2 * i + 1) = Fib (2 * n + 2) := sorry


theorem Exercise_6_4_8a : âˆ€ (m n : Nat),
    Fib (m + n + 1) = Fib m * Fib n + Fib (m + 1) * Fib (n + 1) := sorry


theorem Exercise_6_4_8d : âˆ€ (m k : Nat), Fib m âˆ£ Fib (m * k) := sorry
Hint for #7: Let m be an arbitrary natural number, and then use induction on k. For the induction step, you must prove Fib m âˆ£ Fib (m * (k + 1)). If m = 0 âˆ¨ k = 0, then this is easy. If not, then use exists_eq_add_one_of_ne_zero to obtain a natural number j such that m * k = j + 1, and therefore m * (k + 1) = j + m + 1, and then apply Exercise_6_4_8a.


def Fib_like (n : Nat) : Nat :=
  match n with
    | 0 => 1
    | 1 => 2
    | k + 2 => 2 * (Fib_like k) + Fib_like (k + 1)

theorem Fib_like_formula : âˆ€ (n : Nat), Fib_like n = 2 ^ n := sorry


def triple_rec (n : Nat) : Nat :=
  match n with
    | 0 => 0
    | 1 => 2
    | 2 => 4
    | k + 3 => 4 * triple_rec k +
                6 * triple_rec (k + 1) + triple_rec (k + 2)

theorem triple_rec_formula :
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), triple_rec n = 2 ^ n * Fib n := sorry

10. In this exercise you will prove that the numbers q and r in Example_6_4_1 are unique. It is helpful to prove a lemma first.
lemma quot_rem_unique_lemma {m q r q' r' : Nat}

theorem quot_rem_unique (m q r q' r' : Nat)

11. Use the theorem in the previous exercise to prove the following characterization of n / m and n % m.

title: 6Â  Additional space
text:
6.5. Closures Again
Section 6.5 of HTPI gives one more application of recursion and induction: another proof of the existence of closures of sets under functions. Recall from Section 5.4 that if f : A â†’ A and B : Set A, then the closure of B under f is the smallest set containing B that is closed under f. In Section 5.4, we constructed the closure of B under f by taking the intersection of all sets containing B that are closed under f. In this section, we construct the closure by starting with the set B and repeatedly taking the image under f. For the motivation for this strategy, see HTPI; here we focus on how to carry out this strategy in Lean.
To talk about repeatedly taking the image of a set under a function, we will need a recursive definition:
def rep_image {A : Type} (f : A â†’ A) (n : Nat) (B : Set A) : Set A :=
  match n with
    | 0 => B
    | k + 1 => image f (rep_image f k B)
According to this definition, rep_image f 0 B = B, rep_image f 1 B = image f B, rep_image f 2 B = image f (image f B), and so on. In other words, rep_image f n B is the result of starting with B and then taking the image under f n times. To make it easier to work with this definition, we state two simple theorems, both of which follow immediately from the definition.
theorem rep_image_base {A : Type} (f : A â†’ A) (B : Set A) :
    rep_image f 0 B = B := by rfl

theorem rep_image_step {A : Type} (f : A â†’ A) (n : Nat) (B : Set A) :
    rep_image f (n + 1) B = image f (rep_image f n B) := by rfl
We will prove that the closure of B under f is the union of the sets rep_image f n B. We will call this the cumulative image of B under f, and we define it as follows:
def cumul_image {A : Type} (f : A â†’ A) (B : Set A) : Set A :=
  { x : A | âˆƒ (n : Nat), x âˆˆ rep_image f n B }
To prove that cumul_image f B is the closure of B under f, we first prove a lemma saying that if B âŠ† D and D is closed under f, then for every natural number n, rep_image f n B âŠ† D. We prove it by induction.
lemma rep_image_sub_closed {A : Type} {f : A â†’ A} {B D : Set A}
    (h1 : B âŠ† D) (h2 : closed f D) :
    âˆ€ (n : Nat), rep_image f n B âŠ† D := by
  by_induc
  Â· -- Base Case
    rewrite [rep_image_base]          --Goal : B âŠ† D
    show B âŠ† D from h1
    done
  Â· -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : rep_image f n B âŠ† D   --Goal : rep_image f (n + 1) B âŠ† D
    fix x : A
    assume h3 : x âˆˆ rep_image f (n + 1) B  --Goal : x âˆˆ D
    rewrite [rep_image_step] at h3
    define at h3    --h3 : âˆƒ (x_1 : A), x_1 âˆˆ rep_image f n B âˆ§ f x_1 = x
    obtain (b : A) (h4 : b âˆˆ rep_image f n B âˆ§ f b = x) from h3
    rewrite [â†h4.right]   --Goal : f b âˆˆ D    
    have h5 : b âˆˆ D := ih h4.left
    define at h2          --h2 : âˆ€ (x : A), x âˆˆ D â†’ f x âˆˆ D
    show f b âˆˆ D from h2 b h5
    done
  done
With this preparation, we can now prove that cumul_image f B is the closure of B under f.
theorem Theorem_6_5_1 {A : Type} (f : A â†’ A) (B : Set A) :
    closure f B (cumul_image f B) := by
  define
  apply And.intro
  Â· -- Proof that cumul_image f B âˆˆ { D : Set A | B âŠ† D âˆ§ closed f D }
    define  --Goal : B âŠ† cumul_image f B âˆ§ closed f (cumul_image f B)
    apply And.intro
    Â· -- Proof that B âŠ† cumul_image f B
      fix x : A
      assume h1 : x âˆˆ B
      define     --Goal : âˆƒ (n : Nat), x âˆˆ rep_image f n B
      apply Exists.intro 0
      rewrite [rep_image_base]  --Goal : x âˆˆ B
      show x âˆˆ B from h1
      done
    Â· -- Proof that cumul_image f B closed under f
      define
      fix x : A
      assume h1 : x âˆˆ cumul_image f B  --Goal : f x âˆˆ cumul_image f B
      define at h1
      obtain (m : Nat) (h2 : x âˆˆ rep_image f m B) from h1
      define     --Goal : âˆƒ (n : Nat), f x âˆˆ rep_image f n B
      apply Exists.intro (m + 1) --Goal : f x âˆˆ rep_image f (m + 1) B
      rewrite [rep_image_step]   --Goal : f x âˆˆ image f (rep_image f m B)
      define     --Goal : âˆƒ (x_1 : A), x_1 âˆˆ rep_image f m B âˆ§ f x_1 = f x
      apply Exists.intro x  --Goal : x âˆˆ rep_image f m B âˆ§ f x = f x
      apply And.intro h2
      rfl
      done
    done
  Â· -- Proof that cumul_image f B is smallest
    fix D : Set A
    assume h1 : D âˆˆ { D : Set A | B âŠ† D âˆ§ closed f D }
    define at h1  --h1 : B âŠ† D âˆ§ closed f D
